nodes.text: Firms as contractual organizations emerge to economize on the costs of metering individual input productivity and reducing shirking in team production, and thus improve productive cooperation relative to pure market exchanges
The metering problem: efficient organization requires measuring and apportioning rewards in accord with productivity, but measurement is costly and imperfect
Team production is production where multiple heterogeneous inputs jointly produce an output that is not separable into individual outputs, making individual marginal products hard to observe

When team production and costly metering coincide, organization with a central residual claimant who monitors and can reassign inputs (the classical firm) is induced because it lowers net costs of detecting shirking and disciplining members

If rewards are loosely correlated with individual productivity because of monitoring costs, individuals have incentives to shirk and private realizable costs of shirking are less than true social costs, reducing overall productivity
Costly detection of individual behavior in teams (e.g., observing effort, breaks, or task handling) makes market reallocation and competition among outsiders insufficient to eliminate shirking

Definition and bundle of firm rights: a central party common to contracts who holds the residual claim, observes input behavior, can renegotiate individual contracts, alter membership, and sell residual status
Specialization in monitoring plus residual claimant status aligns monitor incentives to reduce shirking and implement managerial duties (measuring, directing, assigning, terminating)
Assumption: nonpecuniary benefits (leisure, amenities) enter utility; auxiliary assumption: centralization of residual claim reduces net shirking more than decentralized profit sharing in large teams
Implication for organizational forms: profit-sharing is viable for small, self-monitoring teams (partnerships), while centralized residual claims are preferred for large teams and corporations

Types of firms and institutional implications: corporations, partnerships, mutuals, nonprofits, socialist firms, unions and employee committees arise as responses to different metering, monitoring and political constraints

Ownership of inputs: assets with high resale value and detectable user cost tend to be owned (capital equipment) while inputs whose user cost is hard to detect or personal (labor) are more likely hired, affecting absentee ownership and tenancy forms

Corporation-specific implications: dispersed ownership, salability of shares, and voting/proxy mechanisms serve as market-like devices to police managerial shirking by enabling concentrated takeover attempts and capitalization of managerial improvements

Firms as specialized markets: firms collect, collate, and sell information about heterogeneous inputs making intrafirm competition and recombination of resources cheaper than repeated external market search

Broader implications and testable predictions: presence of team production and costly metering are necessary conditions for long-run viability of firms; predictions include prevalence of partnerships in small artistic teams, profit sharing where monitoring costs are high, and greater shirking in nonprofit mutuals lacking capitalized residual incentives
